On mac the eclipse.ini file prepends our jdi.jar file to the boot classpath. The new plugin version numbers break this support.
ie the jar file that used to be in org.eclipse.jdt.debug_3.1.0, but now the jdt.debug plugin is version as 3.2.0.qualifier which puts our jdi.jar in a directory something like org.eclipse.jdt.debug_3.2.0.v20051128

As a result, we're finding apple's jdi implementation instead of our own and getting these errors in the console.

java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.sun.jdi.VirtualMachineManager.createVirtualMachine(Lcom/sun/jdi/connect/spi/Connection;)Lcom/sun/jdi/VirtualMachine;
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.ConnectorImpl.establishedConnection(ConnectorImpl.java:98)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketListeningConnectorImpl.accept(SocketListeningConnectorImpl.java:129)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.StandardVMDebugger$ConnectRunnable.run(StandardVMDebugger.java:78)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:552)

Todd, this is another effect of the MacOS X problem that Apple has decided not to leave the jdi library in tools.jar but to move it into classes.jar. This is non-standard (with respect to Windows and linux) and makes it very hard for IDE providers to achieve platform independence.
For us it means that we have to modify the bootclasspath to work around this problem. Since the bootclasspath is global, modifying it breaks plugin encapsulation and really is an ugly thing to do.

Could you find out why this non-standard move has been done?
I've already filed radar bug 3869178 for this.
